concept.title: ImageConv: Image Converter Library example code

section.title: Description
section.p: ImageConv demonstrates the Image Converter Library API. It shows how to:

li.p: read standard graphics formats (such as .bmp or .gif) into CFbsBitmap objects, from where they can be manipulated and rendered to the screen
save CFbsBitmap objects as files, using a number of formats

section.p: The Image Converter API is called by an engine class CImageHandler. The UI class, CImageAppUi, supplies a dialog that allows the user to choose a particular frame from a multi-frame image (such as an animated .gif), and a dialog that allows the user to save the current image in a particular format.

section.title: Download
section.p: Click on the following link to download the example: ImageConv.zip file
Click: browse to view the example code.

section.title: Build
section.p: The source code for this example application can be found in the directory:
It may be in the directory in which you installed the Symbian platform, or it may be in src\common\developerlibrary\. It includes the two project files needed for building: bld.inf and the .mmp file.
The Symbian build process describes how to build this application. For the emulator, an application called ImageConv.exe is created in epoc32\release\winscw\<udeb or urel>\.

li.p: Click on IMAGECONV to run the application. If using the TechView emulator, this will be in the Extras menu.
A collection of sample files of different formats is included. See the readme.txt in ImageConv\samples\ for notes on the characteristics of each sample file.
Commands are given to the example through its File and Image menus. The commands are:
Open file: opens a graphics file and converts it into a displayable CFbsBitmap object
Save as: saves the current bitmap (CFbsBitmap object) in a selectable format
Zoom in and Zoom out: zooms the current image
Rotate clockwise and Rotate anti-clockwise: rotates the current image
Refresh: reloads the image from file
Select frame: selects a frame from a multi-frame image
